chapter.title: OpenStack Compute Node for Hyper-V
chapter.para: Nova-compute can run as a 32bit service upon Microsoft's Hyper-V Hypervisor allowing Hyper-V compute nodes within an OpenStack Cloud.
Currently the following platforms are supported:

listitem.title: Windows Server 2008r2
listitem.para: Both Server and Core with the Hyper-V role enabled

listitem.title: Windows Server 2012
listitem.para: Server and Core (with the Hyper-V role enabled), and Hyper-V Server

chapter.title: Installation Architecture
chapter.para: The following sections will discuss the how to prepare the Windows Hyper-V node for operation as an Openstack Compute node. Unless stated otherwise, any configuration information should work for both the Windows 2008r2 and 2002 platforms.

section.title: Local Storage Considerations
section.para: Local storage on the compute node needs to have ample storage for storing the virtual machine images running on the compute nodes. You may use a sinlge volume for all, or partition it into an OS volume and VM volume. It is up to the individual deploying to decided.

section.title: How does it work:
section.para: To start a live migration, you just need to issue the following nova command on your controller:

itemizedlist.listitem: 1) The target hosts ensures that live migration is enabled and properly configured in Hyper-V.
2) The target hosts checks if the image to be migrated requires a base VHD and pulls it from Glance if not already available on the target host.
3) The source hosts ensures that live migration is enabled and properly configured in Hyper-V
4) The source hosts initialtes a Hyper-V live migration
5) The source hosts communicates to the manager the outcome of the operation

section.para: Two comamnd line options/flags were added in order to support Hyper-V live migration:

listitem.title: instances_shared_storage
listitem.para: This needed to support "shared nothing" Hyper-V live migrations. It is used in nova/compute/manager.py

listitem.title: limit_cpu_features
listitem.para: This flag is needed to support live migration to hosts with different CPU features. This flag is checked during instance creation in order to limit the CPU features used by the VM.

para.title: Requirements:

itemizedlist.listitem: Hyper-V 2012 RC or Windows Server 2012 RC with Hyper-V role enabled
The instances_path command line option/flag needs to be the the same on all hosts
The openstack-compute service deployed with the setup MSI must run with domain credentials (see below)
You can set the service credentials with: sc config openstack-compute obj="DOMAIN\username" password="password"
